narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Listening to "Podcasts" of other students' small discussions.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I learned to question all of my assumptions about the world and the way I have been taught to categorize it: east v west, global v local, man v woman, us v other, civilized v uncivilized.
More tangibly, I developed very good critical thinking skills in this course and improved my ability to read very dense pieces of feminist theory (which in turn taught me a good dose of philosophy). I also improved my ability to discuss sometimes uncomfortable and almost always intellectually difficult matters in a group, being non-judgemental of myself and the others, and being willing to sit with discomfort and consider its implications.
I learned how to be comfortable with uncertainty in my ideas. I also got better at reading critically and applying concepts to my life.

Introduction to modes of gender and sexuality across the world and how these regimes travel. Approach to understanding transnational power structures in general. Experience with personal essays and final research project
Transnational theory in feminism and queer movements
I felt I broadened my perspectives in so many ways. I feel incredibly lucky to have taken this course.

you gain the tools to begin to think about the world and many different case studies through a lens of transnationalism and transnational feminism, with a constant attempt to define and redefine the term as you go on.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The course was fantastic and truly changed the way I see the world, see myself in it, and interact with information I am told is true. It taught me to ask always " why?" and pull back and question the assumptions made even on the most basic level about gender and sexuality.

The only difficulty was the amount of time I had to be on my laptop for this course, which cannot be remedied really until classes return to in-person. Professor Savci did try to improve the situation (and succeeded) with our podcast experiment (see question one). Professor also decreased our readings a bit.

Strengths: Evren is great, the readings were interesting, and the classroom was very welcoming. The assignments let us apply the readings to our own lives and develop an awareness of our own subjectivites which is one of the themes of the course.
Weaknesses: a couple of the readings were a little dense, but nothing unmanageable

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
See question 2 for ways in which we adapted to COVID.


All the adaptations succeeded in my opinion.
Evren did a great job trying to switch up formats and keep us engaged over Zoom
The Professor was very considerate of student input and allowed for a wide range of approaches to help.

Evren was very considerate and accommodating as far as covid19 policies. We observed a short break halfway through class to help combat zoom fatigue, and generally were able to turn off our screens for a minute or two whenever needed. She was also reasonable with the way she spaced out assignments and she gave a reasonable amount of readings, so that overall you could learn without the workload becoming overwhelming.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
YES! This course taught me new ways of thinking and being critical of all that I am taught in a very constructive way. Even for students not interested in WGSS, this is an important skill. The material itself is absolutely fascinating. It is a perfect balance of theory and practical applications of theory/case studies of different places around the world.

Professor Savci is a caring, deeply engaged, and deeply committed professor who was concerned not only with our learning but with our well-being outside of class.
Yes absolutely. Everyone should take a class like this. It completely challenges the way you see the world.
Definitely even as my first WGSS class, Evren made the classroom very welcoming, and it changed how I think about gender and sexuality.
